svaddiparti wrote:

> Iam trying to find out if there are any patterns. I agree with you
> that it depends on the degree of oupling between methods. Also, I
> think that the number of unit test cases will determine the effort
> required.

Loosely speaking, perhaps, but it's usually the complexity/size of test 
cases, and not the number, that dominates the cost of writing and 
running and maintaining them.

> However, can I come up with an estimate by making some assumptions.
> For eg: the number of parameters required for each method to invoke.
> 
> At the granular level i.e per test case per method, is it possible to
> come up with lines of code (LOC) for JUnit code. If so what are the
> parameters on which the LOC for a particular test case depends on.
> This muct include teh mock classes also.

You could try, but I wouldn't trust those numbers very much. LOC are 
such a poor indicator of time spent writing code, especially when one 
starts to refactor regularly.

All I can suggest is a two-week experiment where you test-drive all new 
features and add tests only when you need them to support your current 
work. After two weeks, measure how quickly you're adding new features. 
This tells you when you'll be done, which is likely more important than 
knowing how much writing tests (alone) costs you.

Good luck.
